title: What will the Federal Open Market Committee decide to do with respect to the federal funds rate at its scheduled March 2017 meeting?
preds: Janet Yellen, chairwoman of the Federal Reserve talked about this, saying that since the job market is good, March is ready for a raising of the federal funds rate.
This is the most signaled news of the year.
There seems to be unanimous agreement among financial analysts that the Fed will announce another raise.

- US employers added jobs at an above-average pace for a second month on outsized gains in construction and manufacturing
- Wage growth picked up, as the labor market continued its steady improvement in the new year
- Job figures provides further ammunition for Fed to hike

Wall Street unanimous on U.S. rate hike next week: Reuters poll
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-fed-poll-idUSKBN16H2MV?il=0
Today's NFP report should seal it, despite other 1Q macro indicators coming in fairly soggy.
Recent strong economic numbers point in direction of a raise in rates in March.
235,000 jobs added in February, unemployment reducing further to 4.7%. With the Fed already signalling a likely rise, these numbers can only increase the probability.

Unemployment rate has continued to decline to approx. 4.7%. Inflation has continued to grow - now at 2.5% for Jan 2017. Fed rate is currently at 0.75% but target is to raise it to 1.5% by the end of 2017 if economy continues to improve. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/10/business/economy/february-unemployment-jobs-report.html?action=Click&contentCollection=BreakingNews&contentID=65008568&pgtype=Homepage

All the economic variables point to a strong US economy and the Fed will want to increase rates to reign in inflation before it gets out of control.
The 5% probability for maintaining is due to the fact that the Fed might want to wait for more clarity on Trump's spending plans. However, there is no evidence of this coming any time soon, whence the low probability.

Recent Yellin remarks make rate hike highly probable

Rationale:
- US Economic data has not surprised to the downside in the wake of Trump's victory; CPI y/y has been on a uptrend (2.5% as of Jan) - PCE however is still below the Fed's inflation target of 2%
- Labour market data has remained in line with expectations; It seems that the US labour market is operating with little spare capacity
- In addition, Trump's "America-First" policies are all positive for inflation - The Fed has to act quickly to be ahead of the inflation curve and bond vigilantes
- 10-year US Treasuries have risen to 2.50% (As of 8 March); Betting markets are now at 96%
- However, the Fed has traditionally given guidance prior to raising rates; Odds rose significantly after end-Feb where Fedspeak was largely hawkish
- Policy uncertainty still prevails; This tempers my expectation of a hike in March.
If there is no last minute surprise it's a done deal

Recent comments from Fed members seem to indicate predilection to raise rates sooner rather than later. Thus, adjusting upwards slightly. Still waiting to see stronger economic fundamentals before going all in.
Statements by several Fed board members unanimously speak of raising rates

What will the Federal Open Market Committee decide to do with respect to the federal funds rate at its scheduled March 2017 meeting?
Forecast: Raise 80 %, Maintain 20% and lower 0%.
The information shown in figure 1 is the monthly development in the effective federal funds rate since July 1954. Remarkable are the peaks of the funds rate in the eighties (maximum? When?) and the extreme minimums around 2010 (minimum? When?). As becomes clear from the graph the development of the federal funds rate is divided in increasing and decreasing trends, the trends lasts for several months and sometimes years. This implies that if the effective federal funds rate has risen in the previous month, the probability of an increase in the rate in the next month is higher than the chance of a decrease. 
Therefore it becomes useful to look at the most recent trend. Figure 2 shows clearly a gradually increasing trend in the effective federal funds rate. This increase started in November 2015, with a rate just above 0.1% and is was between 0,6% and 0,7% in the most recent data. The trend does not seem to have reached it’s peak yet, since it is still gradually increasing until January 2017.
However, the question is not about the effective federal funds rate, but about the targeted federal fund rate by the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC). The decision to use the data of the effective federal funds rate can be justified by showing that the effective federal funds rate usually follow the targeted federal funds rate. If one compares figure 2 & 3, it becomes clear that when the FOMC decided to raise the limit if of the target rate from 0,25% to 0,5% in January 2016, the effective rate increased quickly to a rate just below 0.4% and continued to increase slowly after that time. A similar development is shown when the FOMC raised the limit of the target rate to 0,75% in the end of 2016. Thus, these two figures highly correlate with each other and therefore the effective federal funds rate can be used as an indicator of the targeted federal funds rate by the FOMC. One of the main goals of the Federal reserves is to keep the inflation around 2% (Svensson, 1997, p.1112). Because of the economic crisis the inflation rate was below 2% for a very long time, and therefore the FOMC kept the federal funds rate as low as possible, between 0% and 0,25%. When the interest rates are lowered, LM shifts down leading to a higher output and price level.Yet the inflation is increasing again since the end of 2015 (figure 4) and the FOMC started in begin 2016 to slowly raise the interest to adjust to the rising inflation rate again. Now, the inflation is past the target of approximately 2%, therefore it is likely that the FOMC will execute contractionary monetary policy, increasing the federal funds rate, to shift LM up leading to a relatively lower output and price level. In this way the FOMC can reduce the inflation rate again to the targeted range around 2%.
The second main goal of the FED is to keep unemployment at its natural level. It can be argued that the natural level is around 5%  or even higher (Daly, Hobijn, Sahin & Valletta, 2012, p.5). Figure 5 shows that the unemployment rate has been decreasing since 2010, and recently dropped below 5% (January 2016). Because of the economic crisis unemployment was above the natural rate of unemployment, but because of the very low interest rates and the growing economy it started to drop again. However, in January 2016 unemployment reached the 5% level and dropped below 5%, this correlates with the moment that the FOMC decided to raise the federal funds rate again. The graph shows that unemployment is still below 5% and therefore the FOMC is, again, likely to raise the federal funds rate. In this case LM will shift down, leading to a decrease in investment and in output. Okun’s law states that unemployment then will grow (Blanchard and Johnson, 2013, p. 52).
In conclusion, the FOMC is very likely to raise the federal funds rate for the following reasons. Firstly, the federal funds rate is in an increasing trend and is therefore more likely to be raised than lowered. Furthermore, the main indicators of the federal funds rate, the inflation and the unemployment, are not at their target rate, yet this can be reached by the FOMC if they raise the federal funds rate. Therefore my forecast is that the probability of the FOMC raising the federal funds rate is 80% and the probability of them mainting the rate is 20%.
References:
Blanchard, O. and Johnson, D. R. (2013). Macroeconomics. Pearson, 6th edition
Daly, M. C., Hobijn, B., Şahin, A., & Valletta, R. G. (2012). A search and matching approach to labor markets: Did the natural rate of unemployment rise?. The Journal of Economic Perspectives, 26(3), 3-26.
Svensson, L. E. (1997). Inflation forecast targeting: Implementing and monitoring inflation targets. European economic review, 41(6), 1111-1146.

I assign a higher probability of maintaining rates at the March 2017 meeting because I believe that the correct course of action from the Fed would be to wait for more clarity regarding the plans of the new administration (tax cuts, border-adjustments, etc.).
However I have revised up my probability of the Fed raising rates from 30% because of the recent hawkish messages of the different board members and because of the inflationary pressures building up. Raising rates sooner rather than later also gives them a tool to deploy in the next recession.

I've found that Zerohedge is a usually a good blog for economic trends and I agree with the conclusion of this article: "one of the most profitable bets traders could have made in the last two years is that Fed forecasts would be wrong"

FOMC minutes were published: https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/fomcminutes20170201.htm In the minutes, some voices are members and others are participants; members vote, participants don't. The minutes indicate that participants favour increasing the policy rate fairly soon, whereas members tend to be comfortable with current levels. (Bloomberg article)[https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2017-02-23/whom-to-listen-to-in-the-fed-minutes] JPMorgan economists, in fact, changed their forecast for a June rate hike to May based on the two economic reports. "We still think March is too early for them to hike, particularly given their propensity to prepare markets for a move. Instead, we think March would be a good meeting for them to prepare the markets for a hike at the subsequent meeting on May third," the economists wrote. Most Fed watchers have forecast a June rate hike. Goldman Sachs economists also said that based mostly on the hotter inflation reading, the likelihood of a March hike increased to 30 percent from 20 percent, but they also see a better chance for May. "In short, we now think it is a close call whether the committee will hike the funds rate at the next two meetings or wait until June, and we see very high odds [90 percent] of at least one rate increase by mid-year," they wrote in a note. (CNBC)[http://www.cnbc.com/2017/02/15/a-march-rate-hike-isnt-a-lock-but-the-odds-probably-just-got-better.html]
Updated based on minutes.  Nothing to signal they are preparing the market for a hike.

From the recent minutes of the Federal Open Markets Committee on 1/31-2/1 (https://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/press/monetary/20170222a.htm, pdf version pg. 16): 
"In discussing the outlook for monetary policy over the period ahead, many participants expressed the view that it might be appropriate to raise the federal funds rate again fairly soon if incoming information on the labor market and inflation was in line with or stronger than their current expectations or if the risks of overshooting the Committee’s maximum-employment and inflation objectives increased." It appears that many, but not most, of the committee members were in favor of raising the federal funds rate if unemployment remains low (4.8%) and PCE (personal consumption expenditures) inflation rate rises faster than a desired 2% (currently 1.7% as of Jan). Thus, I believe that if unemployment remains the same or lower, and if inflation rises faster than predicted the Fed will raise rates next month.

The economy was better off three years ago and the FED did not make any substantial moves then. It waited until the economy actually got worse to start raising rates. At the FED keeps saying that they raise rates based on the data, but that is clearly no longer true. They raise rates for political reasons. They raise rates to maintain public confidence. They suggested they were going to raise rates three times in 2015 and we got one extremely small raise at the end of the year. They said they would raise rates multiple times in 2016 and we again got one extremely small raise at the end of the year. If they raised rates again in March after recently raising rates in December that would send a message to the market that they are ready to start raising rates more aggressively. That forward-looking signal would be more meaningful than the raised rate itself. Even with year-to-year CPI at 2.5% they are not going to raise rates in March.

Harker signaled in an interview with Market News International late Monday that he would likely support an interest rate increase at the central bank’s next meeting in March if he sees additional evidence that inflation is gaining momentum.
Waiting too long to raise interest rates would be "unwise" as economic growth continues and inflation rises, Fed Chair Janet Yellen told Congress on Tuesday. Repeating caution that she and other central bank officials have issued in recent months, Yellen said that even though the Fed expects to hike gradually and to keep policy accommodative, getting rates back to normal levels is important and hikes will be considered ahead.
Market reaction was prompt, with government bond yields jumping on sentiment that Yellen was teeing up next month's Fed meeting as possible for a rate hike.
http://www.cnbc.com/2017/02/14/fed-chair-janet-yellen-unwise-to-wait-too-long-to-hike-interest-rates.html

COMMENTS:  The possibility of a raise exists, since the Fed kept its target overnight lending rate near zero for seven years and raised just twice since, in December 2015 and a year later. The FOMC now expects three rate hikes in 2017, two or three in 2018 and three in 2019.

"At our upcoming meetings, the Committee will evaluate whether employment and inflation are continuing to evolve in line with these expectations, in which case a further adjustment of the federal funds rate would likely be appropriate," Yellen said.

Outside view; Since 1971 the FED has raised or lowered rates a total of 119 times.  The FED has moved rates in the month of March 10 times (8%) since 1971.  The month of Dec has the greatest number of FED moves with 23 moves.  If we look the data by broken down by quarter the 4th Q has had 35% of the moves followed by the 1st Q with 26% of the time.  Then followed by the 2nd Q with 20% and the 3rd Q with 19% of the moves. Broken down by month how many times the FED has moved.
Jan = 13
Feb = 8
Mar = 10
Apr = 10
May = 7
June = 6
July = 4
Aug = 11
Sept = 9
Oct = 8
Nov = 10
Dec = 23 https://www.thebalance.com/fed-funds-rate-history-highs-lows-3306135 Comment:  8% of the time March has rate moves.  80% of March rate moves are raises in rates.  The 1st Q has 31% of the rate moves.  The Fed has indicated they are going to raise rates a couple times this year.  Trump announced at the Boing plant that Jobs are "surging" since Nov.  70/30 is a more likely forecast.  But I'm including Trumps comments in my forecast.  Does Trump want rates to rise in March?

Besides: Most economic indicators point in the right direction PLUS inflation is finally kicking in...(which has not been the case for a very long time)

"Consumer prices in the United States increased 0.6 percent month-over-month in January of 2017, higher than 0.3 percent in December and above forecasts of 0.3 percent. It is the highest monthly rate since February of 2013."
http://www.tradingeconomics.com/united-states/inflation-rate-mom
Low unemployment + a modest increase in inflation will give Yellen a chance to give another quarter to the FFR.

The Fed says it expects to raise two or three times this year. However, March seems too early, as the Trump administrations's economic policies are yet to be clarified. Though the unemployment rate suggests the US is close to "full" employment and inflation is starting to reach the Fed's 2% target, other indicators are not as good. Real wages have not increased in the last year, and auto loan defaults are at their highest since 2009, Consequently, consumers in the middle to lower brackets may run into trouble if the rate is increased in March, unless they are given some tax relief.
The Fed has no more idea what HairBoy has in mind than does anyone else, including Himself.  Best course for them is to pretend to be dead for a while.
Trump still has time to botch this thing.

CNBC yesterday:  "JPMorgan economists, in fact, changed their forecast for a June rate hike to May based on the two economic reports.  "We still think March is too early for them to hike, particularly given their propensity to prepare markets for a move. Instead, we think March would be a good meeting for them to prepare the markets for a hike at the subsequent meeting on May third," the economists wrote. Most Fed watchers have forecast a June rate hike.  Goldman Sachs economists also said that based mostly on the hotter inflation reading, the likelihood of a March hike increased to 30 percent from 20 percent, but they also see a better chance for May."  http://www.cnbc.com/2017/02/15/a-march-rate-hike-isnt-a-lock-but-the-odds-probably-just-got-better.html
Compelling reasons to hike, but fiscal outlook unclear and current market prediction is ~78% that they stay pat.

I can see the rational of the Fed increasing in Q1 and Q3. The data is healthy and broad enough to see a rate increase after the risk market pilling on more risk. 
https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/fomcprojtabl20160921.htm

According to Yellen's last statements, 3 raises are expected in 2017. 8 meetings are scheduled for 2017, of which the Jan.-Feb. meeting was the first and did not lead to a rate change. The last change was in the December meeting. That would indicate a 50:50 probability between the March and May meetings. Given her recent indication that it would be 'unwise' to delay I give a slightly higher probability to add-on increase in the March meeting.  Sources
